titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Jamaica Office of Police records 1977.096
titlestmt.author: Matthew Gorham
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-08-25 13:41:32 +0000.

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Jamaica (New York, N.Y.). Office of Police

did.abstract: The Jamaica Office of Police records span the period 1780 to 1782 and consist of three handwritten documents. Two of the documents concern the repair of highways in Queens County and Kings County, New York, while the third document states that Aaron Von Nostrant, Marshall of the Jamaica Office of Police, is empowered to inspect the weight and quality of bread sold in Jamaica.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition unknown. The records were formally accessioned in 1977.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Jamaica Office of Police records, 1977.096, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.
